reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: THE SCREENSHOTS ON THE STORE PAGE ARE NOT AN ACCURATE DEPICTION OF THE GAME, AS OF V. 0.9.4, WHICH I HAVE BEEN PLAYING ON.

It's like a top-down Terraria, which is fantastic. This means there isn't platforming, but rather strafing (M+KB), but apart from that much of the gameplay is similar. I will add here that the sprite work is WAY better than Terraria's and though you get less customization overall (1 helm slot, 1 armor slot, 3 accessory slots), I expect this to change as the game develops.

The farming in this game is absolutely fantastic and mesmerizing, easy to pick up and satisfying to do (also super quick, though I expect this to be tweaked later; currently it's way too easy to just farm up a few hundred loaves of bread and solve your hunger forever).

This is a criminally overlooked game, probably because in-game there's no guidance whatsoever (might change but I hope it doesn't; discovery is great in it as it is currently).

Pros:

- Simple and easy controls, mechanics
- Visually beautiful - I expect there to be more variety as the game develops as well
- Familiar gameplay progression (build X to build Y, which lets you build Z, etc.)
- Farming is satisfying and rewarding (best foods through farming AFAIK)
- Exploration is satisfying and rewarding (required to get forging materials, early on you get some good stuff through just walking around)
- You can raise your own pigs/sheep/chicken, something that is often overlooked in many games like this. Unlike Minecraft where you had to gimmick rooms to spawn cows/sheep/whatever before, ranching is built into the game here.
- Auto-detect nearby crafting stations so you're not always switching back and forth for a single item. Bunch up your related crafting stations.
- A lot to do in-game despite early access

Cons (NOTE: The game is EA when I write this review, I expect most of these to be solved on launch because they are quite significant IMO)

- No multiplayer yet. I would be very sad if the game finished without multiplayer, this seems like a REALLY fun MP game.
- Hunger rate needs reworking IMO, currently it drops a bit too fast so you're forced to spend a lot of time foraging until you build a farm, after which your hunger issues go from urgent" to "non-existant" really fast
- Saves lag my PC for unknown reasons
date: this is really annoying with auto-save as the game sill simply freeze for about 2-3 seconds every 12-hours in-game time.\n- No way to make multiple items at once (shiftclick
voteText: etc.); really annoying when you have 1000 logs and need to turn half of those into sticks.\n- No way to split stacks of items
helpfulPercent: gotta move them wholesale.\n- Item organization button would be extremely useful tbh
votesHelpful:
it's annoying to manually have to move items every time you craft something.
- Monster variety could probably be expanded a bit.
- Updates are slow. AFAIK the team is super small so don't expect this to fully release any time soon. The game is definitely playable but not finished.


Also under cons
votesTotal:
but more bug-related:

- Items never disappear from the map (they just blink forever)
- You can activate doors and refill troughs from across the screen
commentsCount: for an EA game it's surprisingly well polished and I'm really looking forward to release. Honest 9/10 if you don't count the mildly annoying bugs that come with the game not being finished."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Forsaken IsleDeveloper: Smoodlez
Publisher: Smoodlez

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an informative review. No other compensation was given.


Introduction
==========
Ahoy matey! Me ship crashed on this island
date: leavin' me alone on this godforsaken island. It's up t' me t' find a way t' survive! This be a survival craftin' game
voteText: and other games in t' genre. I have t' collect resources t' make what I need t' get by. Fightin' monsters
votesHelpful:
makin' food...all be skills that I will need t' survive on this mesterious island."


Gameplay
==========
Forsaken Isle literally dumps you onto a large island with next to nothing. There is no story
votesTotal: except for what is found on the store page. You play as a pirate whose ship crashed on this island. You don't start with anything. You'll have to forage for supplies and gather resources to build and craft tools to build and survive. The first night is very important
votesFunny: as you should be able to build some walls around yourself with a campfire to light your area
commentsCount: to ward off monsters.\n\nThere is a somewhat robust character creator (robust for this type of game with it's graphics)
column18: and other features. There is also a random option.\n\nAs you discover new materials and resources
column19: new recipes are made available to you. But it's your job to discover them and put them to use! This is one of the fun aspects of any survival game: figuring out what does what
column21: and what's useless. You can also find/craft weapons and armor
column23:
such as increased defense or movement speed.

Graphics
==========
Forsaken Isle is entirely pixel based. Everything looks really crisp and detailed for being sprite-based. While this isn't a heavy 3D modelled game like something from a AAA title
column24: it works. The retro pixel style they've used here is very appealing
column27: and armor all change how your character looks. Put on a Wolf Helm
column28:
you'll see a wolf head on your character. Holding a sword? You'll see the wooden sword being brandished.


Sound and Music
==========
This is the game's lowest point: There is absolutely NO music in the game whatsoever. MOst everythign has a sound effect though: sword slashes
column31: picking up items...but no music. Not even ambient sound effects like crickets or whatnot. Being an Early Access title
column32: it is safe to assume that the music is just not ready to be implemented yet
column33: and I'm sure it will be in the future. For now
column34:
this is a great game to play with your own playlist blasting in the background!


Performance
==========
In the dozen hours I played I ran into no issues with the game. No FPS drops
column36: no stuttering. It's a very minimal game
column37: no one should have any issues running Forsaken Isle. Heck
column38:
even a toaster could run it!


Final Thoughts
==========
A worthy entry into the survival genre that's not an obvious copy of another title
column39: it's almost too good to be true! With some great systems and gameplay already set in place
column40: Forsaken Isle should shape up nicely in the coming months as it runs through Early Access. If you don't want to drop the $8 on it now
column41: just keep an eye out for the next few updates. Even if you do buy it now and are disappointed
column42:
$8 isn't as much as some of the AAA titles that have bombed recently and there's a chance it'll shape up into something you'd enjoy later.


Gameplay Demo
==========
https://youtu.be/wrrHsEeT9xU


Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Recommended

Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing game, just what I was looking for BUT I really wish it would get updated more often. Looking at past updates it seems like it only gets update once every few months. Also, being so close to 1.0 (its already at 0.9.4) it really doesn't appear to have enough content. It becomes quite boring and repetitive after a few hours.

Additions I would like to see:
-portable light system
-more cooking recipes ( a lot more)
-more armor/clothes variants
-more enemy variants
-different types of fishing poles and bows
-fish that are specific to certain areas (underground and swamp)
-more magic items
-possibly a small hidden village for bartering
-actually have to grow food for animals instead of just clicking trough

This game has so so so so much potential and I really hope the dev(s) take full advantage of it. With just a bit more work this could easily be a indie goty and worth $10-$15.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Forsaken Isle is a sandbox crafting game where you start with nothing and advance by crafting more powerful tools and weapons (wood to stone to copper, etc) while exploring the region and fighting monsters.  Although it is Early Access, it is very stable and fun, but could use a bit more polish.  I'm still having a lot of fun crafting items and designing my home base, however.

PROS
+ Simple, effective controls make gathering items and fighting monsters a breeze
+ Large overworld with multiple biomes and underground cave systems to explore
+ Building house/farm/base is easy and fun
+ Progressive crafting and hunger systems encourage exploration
+ Charming graphics

CONS
- Experimenting to find recipes is fun and rewarding at first, but quickly grows very frustrating
- No tutorial, quests, or instructions makes the initial hour of the game seem a bit daunting
- Dragging items from inventory to storage or crafting window sucks (needs a Shift-Click to move" setting BADLY)
- No storyline or quests makes it seem a little lifeless
- Minimal sound effects and virtually no music"
voteText: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far I am very pleased with this game. It has everything you would ever need in an island survival game, even pizza! Besides that, it still has an interesting crafting system and plenty of mobs to 'engage' with. Worth the price if you are willing to gather enough in order to make some really neat farms, caves, and bases. Best part about that, is it doesn't take much to gather all these resources. You do not have to fight a million mobs constantly just for iron ore in the underground systems! It's all very simple and thought out (however I do recommend the wiki, as there is tons of stuff to try out!).

Overall, a relaxing game that should be constantly added to and, honestly, it should be more popular.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minecraft, Terraria, Stonehearth... All are great Survivor/Collector/Adventurer/Builder games.

Forsaken Isle puts a fresh spin on these greats with an early access, but solid concept with the appeals of some of my personal favorite types of games. After my first few deaths from starvation, wraiths, and other carnivorous monsters, I began to get the hang of this little game. before long, I was mining ores for weapons and armor, farming too much food to eat, and catching the all too cute piggies for my pig pin. I've been chopping through forests, fighting tribal tiki people deep in marshy jungles, and fought hordes of zombie pirates and goo balls in the cavernous depths below my growing homestead. before I knew it, 6 hours of my life were gone, and I had only bought it 7 hours ago.

there's plenty going on in this game for an early access, and I'm hoping there will be a consistent updating... Forsaken Isle could go places on the right track.

As for what attracted and hooked me in to this? Well...
-Terraria-esque, pixel-art graphics paired with an overview, fixed angle camera, gives the feel of good old' Dungeon Crawlers.
-painfully simple controls make the learning curve a breeze, and easy to get in to.
-Collect, craft, and survive a rugged land full of monsters, mysteries, and many things to explore.
-An interesting crafting system encourages you to discover new items through trial and error.
-A simple and clean farming system; no watering, no fancy irrigation layouts, just a tilled plot of land and an interesting selection of fruits and veggies.
-Thwack, smack, and slash monsters with an array of weapons from swords to boomerangs, to blowpipes and throwing knives.
-wide variety of crafting stations start you from humble wood and stone tools to the fancy living style of jewelry and pizza.

--The biggest of my qualms that I have with the game is the rapid pace that your hunger bar drops, leaving you scurrying around for food, or dying of starvation (it will happen... more frequent than you'd think.).
--Armor, you get a head, torso, and 3 accessory slots for the likes of rings, boots, etc.
I'd like to see boot/leggings get their own slot, and maybe some sort of shielding... but perhaps it's best in its simplicity.
--my other issue, it a small one... the sounds... there's a squawking bird that could come down an octave or two, but that's why they made mute buttons.

Altogether, Forsaken Isle, with its retro pixel art graphics, easy to learn aspects like farming and fighting, will quickly have you losing hours off your day. And if you're a fan of the likes of Minecraft and Terraria, this needs to be in your Library.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the vein of games like Dwell and Wayward comes Forsaken Isle.

This review is for Early Release:

Pros: Lots of craftables and Crafting Stations to make.
Lots of things to keep you occupied.
Lots of enemies to run around killing.

Cons: Crafting is trial and error. You spend a lot of time figuring out what makes what. (Just part of the fun imo)
Combat is repetitive and easy. (You just basically stand there against an object that an enemy will clip on and hold the mouse button down, not very exciting...)
Guides with complete crafting recipe lists are few and far between...

Overall, it's fun to play and explore this Forsaken Isle. The atmosphere of the game is very pixely and crunchy.
There is a lot of stuff to do, even though the game is not fully finished or released yet. Also, there is a lot of stuff planned for the game that seems to be sending it in the right direction. :)

All in all, I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of survival or wilderness survival open world games. :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is almost like a 2d, top-down minecraft splashed with some Terraria. The gameplay is pretty soild though there is a bit of a learning curve. It's not difficult, but it's a good idea to keep in mind that you'll probably want to start a new character at least once after you get the hang of how the game works.
They switched up the graphics compared to the screenshots, there's an actual clock in the top center of the screen which is pretty nice.

There is one thing that is pretty annoying though: Occasionally at dawn or dusk the game will crash. Not a clue why. But the game's autosave does a nice job and you literally can pick up exactly where it crashed. Thus far I have not lost anything due to this random crash. Just an annoyance at this point.

But it is still in early access, thus for what it is, I would recommend.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those games where even though it's in early access, it is still playable. The wiki needs a lot of work to catch up with all the changes being made.
Take 'Don't Starve' and any of the early 'Harvest Moon' games, swirl them together, pour into a 16 bit mold and you get 'Forsaken Isle'.
Without the wiki, the learning curve would be overwhelming. There is no tutorial. You stand up on the world/land you will be playing on. You can customize your character a bit, although with 16 bit graphics, it doesn't matter much. There is no prompt for a name because this is a single player game and you should already know your name.
To craft, open your inventory and move items from left to the right area. When you have the ability to craft something with any of those combination of items, it will be listed below. Click on the item and it's made.
Watch your food. Hunger hurts and if you don't pay attention. you can suddenly start taking damage and have no clue where it's coming from. This can make your character run around in circles while you (the player) panic and reach to your phone ready to call 991... er... That didn't happen, really. It probably won't happen to you either.

For this early access game, I say yes, it's worth the price. At the very least, it'll show Smoodlez I enjoyed it. You'll have to decide for yourself if you do.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCurrently I am only about 3 hrs into the game, but so far I am loving it! I love crafting/survival games so this is right up my alley. If I didn't like anything about it it would be that you just have to play around with your inventory and guess how to make things. It doesn't give you any help with how to make things until you've already made it. Also, and this could be a problem personal to me, but when I save the game it freezes and it doesn't give me any notification that it is actually saving. It does the same thing when it autosaves - it just freezes the game for a few seconds. Typically I don't mind this, but it's usually because it has some kind of loading bar or wheel or something to let me know the game didn't just crash. Otherwise it is an excellent game and I can see myself playing it a lot!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overview:
Very fun game even though in early access, with many of crafting recipies to discover and a few stuctures to build. I've plaid a fair bit and still haven't crafted half the items in this game. The doungen only becomes interesting after going a couple of levels down, the first few are very familiar and empty. I found a portal, which i couldn't find any access into, and a maze which had an alter but didn't know what to do with it so i assumed these where unfinished developments. Very interested in finding out oneday though. I found myself getting lost without a map of some kind, especially in the lower doungen. Farming is great, crops grow too fast though, by the end of a 3 hour run i had a mass of carrots building up which pretty much kept me fed the entier game. Little confused about which crafting station i was activly using as there is no indication however the GUI is beautiful, loved it. Never got close to using magic in this game, its really a end-game" mechanic unless you know the crafting recipies to begin with. Interested to try adventure mode next. I found there to be not much verity of mobs
recommended: they where also really weak and easy to kill. I would love to see more go into this game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even with just a few hours put into the game so far (3 as of writing this review) I have added this ga to my favorites list and am absolutely in love with it!

The gameplay works great, moving and interacting with the environment is intuitive enough that learning the controls isn't frustrating (because there is no in-game tutorial to teach you how to move or use things). WIth just a little experimentation I was able to understand how to play the game.

The art style is very fun, and overall very well done. The way the game plays with pixel art effects is fantastic and makes the whole style tie together. Unlike some pixel art games that look like the developer was attempting to be lazy with the graphics, Forsaken Isle looks well polished and refined.

The lack of a tutorial is both a pro and a con in my book, depending on how you look at it. Pro: it gives the game a lot more feeling. You really have to learn everything to survive. Con: before you can play, you have to learn the basic controls on how to move and interact with stuff. I would assume that our character knew how to walk and pick up rocks before he became Forsaken on this Isle.

Another thing is the lack of a full-featured save system. You can save your game, but only one game. I haven't really found this to be an issue because I love just taking a few minutes to go into my Isle and do some farming or build another room for my house and having this long-running story where I'm focused on just one character. But on the other hand, I am currently working on an introductory steam guide for the game and would love to have the ability to quickly choose between loading different save files so I could have a main save file for playing and a different one for taking pictures or exploring for the guide.

I realize this game is still in Early Access so any negatives stated above could very well be fixed by the time the game is finished. Some other early access problems that exist right now is the lack of usage for crafting tables or resources. Some crafting tables have very few things you need them for (so far the only recipe for the cooking table is pizza, unless there's one I haven't discovered) and some resources have very few uses. I expect problems like these to sort themselves out though as the game progresses.

All in all this is a fun game! It is definitely poised to become one of my favorites!

My rating for the current alpha version (v.0.9.0): 8.5/10

But by the end of Early Release, I can easily see this game becoming a 10/10!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[I'm only posting a review to add a positive recommendation, so I won't go into detail.]

So far I find this game very relaxing. There's no jumping on platforms (like Terraria), no risk of falling down/jump on the wrong spot, etc.
You just walk around, gather, digging, explore, discovering new recipes. crafting. Sure there's action and killing if you want but if you don't feel like it you won't/barely have to as long as you built yourself a safe place.

I'm not a fan of waiting a long time for nights to end. In Forsaken Isle, nighttime duration is tuned very well imo. So far I spent the nights to sort my gathered loot/mats and put it in storage, replenish your tools, bandages. ammo and food, maybe discover some new recipes. And when I'm done it won't take long for sunrise.

Forsaken Island has plenty for both action and relaxing players, and the game has a very nice price as well. Recommended!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

--Early Access review--
I have not played it much so take that into consideration. I also have not played it in a while. But what I remember is overall game play was okay fun wise. Crafting, on the other hand, is a pain in the ♥♥♥. Other reviewers mentioned that you have to try and try and try again different things in order to find recipes. One reviewer said in his opinion he liked that. My opinion is it's a crappy way to design a game. Or anything really. Unless the game itself is ABOUT discovering recipes.

Maybe I'm misremembering what the game is about. But from what I recall we are basically stranded on an island. A pirate island maybe? Who cares? To me it's about survival and adventure. Exploring. But if any one of us were to be 'stranded' on an island we wouldn't suddenly find that everything we'd learned in life before was poof, gone! We'd still know what a hammer is and nails. A saw and a knife. We'd know what the frack a stick was and we could, quite easily, fashion a bloomin spear or hatchet(thought maybe not very effective ones) from handy materials WITHOUT having to craft some convoluted 'crafting station' to do so.

To me crafting is annoying and filled with frustrations. I ended up opening my browser to look up recipes. To mw that's NOT a well designed game. What happens if the info gets deleted or the recipes change? It IS early access after all. The developer recently added in a crafting book. I think with that he's on the right track to fixing one of the primary reasons why I quit playing the game. He claims he plans on adding to it so that we get hints or something on how to proceed and  craft other interesting or needed items. I hope so. But now we come to the second main reason I don't recommend the game in it's current state. Updates are extremely rare. So rare it makes me wonder if he's lost his motivation or interest in continuing the game.

My recommendation is wait. The game isn't much fun as it is. In fact, I've been considering uninstalling it and putting it in a steam 'category' that I use for hiding games I don't play. So that's basically $8-$10 down the drain unless the dev/'s release more updates which remove the annoyance factors from the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I only played this for 15 minutes, it was more then enough time to tell me I wouldn't like it.

1st off, nothing is explained, there is no tutorial. I managed to create a hammer, but since there are no explanations, I didn't know what it was good for. I found some boots, but didn't know what to do with them or where to put then for them to be useful. I found a torch, but I couldn't use it or place it or do anything with it. After hitting every key on the keyboard and clicking the mouse madly, I just gave up on it and this game.

What I guess is night came, I was instantly surrounded and killed. Gee, that makes a lot of sense, on the first night, most games try to atleast give you a chance to survive. I should also mention, night comes fast, you won't have time to do much of anything.

Crafting is hit or miss. You throw items into the crafting window and hope you can make something out of it. There are no recipes for anything, you get to try to figure it all out by yourself. Only thing you have is a tech tree to see what items you've discovered, by what you've picked up. I couldn't even figure out how to make an axe, and I'm not new to crafting games. 2nd game, I couldn't even find a stick (I'm pretty sure you need one for something).

You also have hunger which goes down remarkedly fast.  I couldn't keep up with it. The other 2 were health and what I guess is energy. Again, no explanations for anything.

I noticed in the key features it states free updates" So what
date: you were considering charging for updates?\n\nUnless you're a die hard fan of this game
recommended: the only thing you'll be doing after trying it out is deleting it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, so this is a preliminary review, but so far I have to say I am loving this game.

I don't really have a list of pros and cons to go over, but so far this game has been a very polished experience. I haven't had too much time to play it, but for the length of time it has been out it is very well rounded game. The best description I can give is that it is like a top-down version of Minecraft. The crafting system in particular is very nice, especially with how it shows you what can be built with what you have through the Recipe Book.

The only complaints I have at the moment are lack of variety and the scarcity of ores. Once you have a base established it can be rather repetitive (farm, get wood, look around underground a bit, repeat), but the game is still expanding, so that will probably change. Finding usable ores can be difficult, as enemies can come at you from all sides underground.

As for suggestions, I would like to see other islands to be traveled to, with different environments, like alpine or volcanic. Maybe introduce a way to build a ship, or summon one with a ghost pirate compass. This game has a ton of potential, and I can't wait to see where it goes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is almost the game that I have always wanted to play ...

Only two hours in and having great fun. I have a couple of little issues with the controls and interface but this is early access so I'm unsurprised. The dev looks like he's interacting with the community a lot which is great to see; it was that which persuaded me to buy it in the first place.

Game play is fun. Bopping around the island with a spear murdering evil pigs is always good for a laugh and the depth of crafting is impressive. I like the fact that all the recipes aren't handed to you on a plate. Experimentation makes it feel a lot more survival orientated.

I haven't got all that far yet but from what I have played I can wholly reccomend this game to anyone who loves Don't Starve, Gnomoria, Terraria or even Minecraft. I just hope that the dev's obvious love for his game doesn't run dry before it's finished.

Early Access Review

Simply an incredible piece of work! I love this game through and through, its entirely developed by one person and is just so much fun. The crafting, atmosphere, and overall art scheme is my favorite in this type of genre. Its a nice casual survival game with some great crafting that keeps you interested to just see what else you can make!

With the recent updates it has balanced the underground (which at one point was nearly impossible to adventure too due to insane amount of enemies spawning). The combat is well balanced and fun, and isn't unfair in anyway. With the recent update though I will say the combat became easy, maybe too easy but still fun. Buy it on sale or full price, either way you'll be satisfied.
